_header: For why that God is inwardly the wit / Of man
Note:
Ringler Jr. (1992)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler , TM 429; Ringler Jr. (1988)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse Printed 1476-1558. London: Mansell, 1988, TP 428.5
Bibliographic Ghosts:
Oxford, Bodleian Library Eng. theol. e.15 (from Hamer (1995)
XHamer, Richard. A Manuscript Index to the Index of Middle English Verse. London: British Library, 1995); see Oxford, Bodleian Library Eng. poet. e.15 (SC 32401); Raines MS (unidentified); f. 2: perhaps now Aberystwyth, National Library of Wales Peniarth 481, below
_description: Benedict Burgh, ‘Cato Major’ — rhyme royal plus three ababbcbc stanzas of ‘Lenvoye’ at the end

BodEngPoete15.First Lines:
ffor þi þat god is inwardly þe wytof man and yeuith
                    him vnderstondyng…
BodEngPoete15.Last Lines:
…Her shal ye fynde þat you may gyde & ledeStreyght to
                    good fame & lede you to hir hous
BodEngPoete15.Attributed Title:
Explicit hic Cato dans castigamina nato (f.
                    36v)

BodRawC48.First Lines:
ffor why that god is inwardli the witteOff man and yeueth hym
                    vndirstondyng…
BodRawC48.Last Lines:
…Bi too and too my metre for to knytteNat causethe me but
                    sympilnesse of witte
BodRawC48.Note:
Each stanza preceded by Latin couplet; the first by, ‘Si deus
                        est animus nobis vt carmina dicunt / Hic tibi precipue sit pura mente
                        colendus’ (f. 84)
BodRawC48.Editions:
Förster,  Max. 
             “Die Burghsche Cato-Paraphrase.” 
             Archiv für das Studium der neueren Sprachen und
                Literaturen
         115 (1905): 298-323; 116 (1906): 25-40: 304-23; 325-34.

BodRawPoe32.First Lines:
ffor why that god is inwardly the wit[ ]Of man and yeueh hym
                    vnderstond[ ]…
BodRawPoe32.Last Lines:
…Bi too & too my metre for to knytnat causith me but
                    simplenesse of wit
BodRawPoe32.Note: The edge of the folio has been cropped off
BodRawPoe32.Attributed Title: Explicit hic Cato dans castigamina nato (f. 29v)

BodRawPoe35.First Lines:
…With mene estate that halt him aggreablePlente and pouerte
                    be nat suffrable…
BodRawPoe35.Last Lines:
…Be two and two my metre for to knytteNat causeth me but
                    simpilnesse of witte
BodRawPoe35.Note: Missing lines 1-376 due to loss of folio(s)

CULEe431.First Lines:
ffor thy that god ys inwardely the WyttOf men and yeueth hem
                    vndyrstandynge…
CULEe431.Last Lines:
…By two and two my metyr for to knyttNought causeth me but
                    symplenes of wytt
CULEe431.Note:
With Latin couplet above each stanza, beginning above first, Si deus
                        est animus nobis vt Carmina dicunt…

CULFf16.First Lines:
Chaunge not thi ffreende that thou knowest of ooldeffor eny newe in
                    trust that thou shalt find…
CULFf16.Last Lines:
…[ ]at partayneth to thy techinge[ ]er neuer [ ] for thy
                    levyng
CULFf16.Note:
40 stanzas, beginning with 32, in disarranged order; part of f. 185 torn
                    away
CULFf16.Facsimiles:
Beadle,  Richard,  and  Alfred E. B. Owen.  
             The Findern Manuscript: Cambridge University Library MS. F.1.6.
         London: Scolar Press, 1977.

CULFf49.First Lines:
ffor that god is inwardly the wytteOf man and yevithe hym
                    vndirstondinge…
CULFf49.Last Lines:
…Here haue I found þat shall þou gyde &
                    ledeStreyte to good fame and leve you in here hous
CULFf49.Note:
Latin prose textsw preceding each stanza, beginning f. 88v
Sideus est animus nobis…

CULHh412.First Lines:
ffor why that god is inwardli [ ]Of man and [
                    ]ing…
CULHh412.Last Lines:
…whan ȝe it rede lat not ȝowr hert be thensdoth as
                    thys saith wt al ȝowr hoole entent
CULHh412.Note: Latin lines at heading of each stanza
CULHh412.Attributed Title:
Title beginning ‘S’ (f.1); Explicit Liber parui Catonis
                    (f. 30)
CULHh412.Editions:
Förster,  Max. 
             “Die Burghsche Cato-Paraphrase.” 
             Archiv für das Studium der neueren Sprachen und
                Literaturen
         115 (1905): 298-323; 116 (1906): 25-40: 304-23; 325-34.

CamJes56.First Lines:
[F]or why þat god is inwardly þe wittOf man and yeueth
                    hym vndirstondyng…
CamJes56.Last Lines:
…By two and two my metre for to knyteÞat can it haue bot
                    symplenes of witt
CamJes56.Note:
Latin couplet as heading to each stanza; first Latin begins,
                        ‘Si deus est animus nobis.…’

CamMagPep2006.First Lines:
ffor why that god is in warldy thy wytteOf man and yeveth hym
                    vnderstondyng…
CamMagPep2006.Last Lines:
…Than rede Macer in his old diteeWheche tellyth alle men in
                    her propre qualite
CamMagPep2006.Note:
45 stanzas; ends imperfectly at line 360. Latin lines at heading of each
                    stanza, first is [S]I deus est animus nobis ut carmina dicunt hic tibi
                        precipue sit picta mente colendus
CamMagPep2006.Facsimiles:
Edwards,  A. S. G. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Manuscript Pepys 2006: A Facsimile. Magdalen College,
                Cambridge.
         Norman, OK: Pilgrim, and [Woodbridge, Suffolk]: Boydell and Brewer,
            1985.

CamTCC1157.First Lines:
Enforce thy wyttes for to lereAquaynt the wyth connyng for it is
                    sureYf fortune chaunge and pouerte a perehe that ys connynge ys lyke
                    to recure
CamTCC1157.Note:
Stanza 131 only; formerly 726 and Ringler Jr. (1992)
XRingler Jr.,  William A. 
             Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript
                1501-1558.
         London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by 
                Michael
                Rudick
             and 
                Susan J.
                Ringler
             TM 381
CamTCC1157.Editions:
Person,  Henry Axel. 
             Cambridge Middle English Lyrics.
         Seattle: University of Washington Press, 1953; rev. ed. 1962: 49.

BLAdd29729.Transcription:
sum wemen wepyn of peure feminitewhan othar wysse they can not theyr
                    intentachyve but yet beware of suche nyce pitethy manly reson
                    forþat it be not blentfor swiche wepynge thyn hert may not
                    relentsome wemen of kynd evar wepynge& vndarþat can they
                    bothe pryke & stynge

BLAdd34193.First Lines:
ffor that god is inwardely the witteOf man and yefeth hym
                    vndrestondynge…
BLAdd34193.Last Lines:
…Here haffe I funde that shall yow gyde and ledeStright to
                    gode fame and leve yow in hire howse

BLAdd38179.First Lines:
For why that God is in wurdly thy wytteOf man and geveth hym
                    onderstondyng…
BLAdd38179.Last Lines:
…Than rede Macer in his old DiteeWheche tellyth alle men in
                    here propre qualite

BLAru168.First Lines:
ffor þat god is Inwardly þe witteOf man and shewith hym
                    vnderstandynge…
BLAru168.Last Lines:
…Be two and two my meture for to knyttNought causith me but
                    simplenes of witt
BLAru168.Note: Each stanza preceded by two lines of Latin, as usual.
BLAru168.Attributed Author: Explicit hic Cato dans Castigamina Nato
BLAru168.Attributed Title: Explicit hic Cato dans Castigamina Nato

BLHar43.First Lines:
…But yf thou kepe þin thy name þou sleystTo serue
                    thy behest do thow thy cure…
BLHar43.Last Lines:
…Take pacyently pouert for the bestRyches comyth not of nature
                    but of quest…
BLHar43.Note:
A fragment, comprising a single leaf, recto and verso, at front of MS:
                    lines 87-147.

BLHar116.First Lines:
For thy that god gaf inwardli the witteOf man and yeueth hym
                    vndirstondyng…
BLHar116.Last Lines:
…By tuo and tuo my meter for to knytteNought causeth me but
                    simplenes of witte…
BLHar116.Note:
In rhyme royal stanzas, each preceded by a Latin couplet, beginning,
                        ’Si deus est animus nobis Vt carmina dicunt / Hic tibi precipue sit
                        pura mente colendus’; with two 8-line stanza envoy to part 1 (f.
                        106r-v), three 8-line stanza envoy to parts 2 (f.
                    112v) and 3 (f. 117r-v), and only explicit title at end of
                    part 4.
BLHar116.Attributed Title: Explicit liber Catonis transpositus in Anglicum (f. 124)

BLHar172.First Lines:
[F]or whi þat god ys Inwardly the wyttOf man & yevithe hym
                    vnderstandynge…
BLHar172.Last Lines:
…By too & too my metre for to knytteNought cavsythe me but
                    Symplenes of wytt
BLHar172.Note:
Followed on f. 71 by motto, ‘Soli deo honor et
                    gloria’, written by scribe
BLHar172.Attributed Author:
John lydgate (written below first four lines by Stow, then crossed
                    through, f. 52)

BLHar271.First Lines:
ffor thi god that is inwardli þe whittof mann & yeff
                    þe þi vnderstondyng…
BLHar271.Last Lines:
…And thus no better in metur for to kl knyttWhat
                    causeth me but sempilness of wytt
BLHar271.Note:
In penultimate line ‘kl’ written and crossed through before
                    ‘knytt’ (f. 44v).
BLHar271.Attributed Author:
Magistrum benedyctum Berrh vicarius de Maldone in essex (f.
                        44v)
BLHar271.Attributed Title:
Explicet liber catonys compest per Magistrum benedyctum Berrh vicarius
                        de Maldone in essex (f. 44v)

BLHar2251.First Lines:
FOr that god is inwordly the witOf man and yevith hym
                    vnderstandyng…
BLHar2251.Last Lines:
…And I dare sey of wisdam and of wittPlente and foyson therin
                    shul ye fynde
BLHar2251.Note:
Followed, as if part of the same work, by stanzas 2 & 3 of ‘A
                    Moral Balade’ (3645).

BLHar4733.First Lines: fforthy that god ys inwardly the wyttOf man and ȝeueth hym vndurstondynge…
BLHar4733.Last Lines: …By to & too my metur for to knyttNaught causeth but simpelnes of witt
BLHar4733.Note: Preceded by Latin prose before each section, in rubric; the first begins “Si deus est.”
BLHar4733.Attributed Title: Explicit liber catonis compositus per Magistrum Benedictum Burgh (rubric, f. 30)

BLHar7333.First Lines:
ffor thi that god is inwardly the wytteOf man and yevith him
                    vndirstondyng
BLHar7333.Last Lines:
Be two and too my metre for to knytNoght causith me but symplenesse
                    of witte

BLRoy18Dii.First Lines: When it is tyme of coste and greate expens.Beware of waste and spende be measure…
BLRoy18Dii.Last Lines: …Vnder the whiche ye may fynde in your aduertens.A swete carnell of wysdam and of goode sentens.
BLRoy18Dii.Note: Selections only, 168 lines, in disarranged order.
BLRoy18Dii.Attributed Title: The prouerbes in the sydis of the Innere chamber abouen of the house in the garding at Wresill (f. 207, in rubric)
BLRoy18Dii.Facsimiles:
Digital Facsimile of British Library MS Royal 18 D II.
         2015; http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Royal_MS_18_D_II.
BLRoy18Dii.Editions:
Grose,  Francis. 
             The Antiquarian Repertory.
         4 vols. London, 1775; 2nd ed., 1779-84; new ed. London: Jeffery,
            1807-09: 4.411.
Flügel,  Ewald. 
             “Kleinere Mitteilungen aus handschriften: Die proverbs von Lekenfield
                und Wreksil (Yorks.)” 
             Anglia
         14 (1892): 471-97: 489-93.
Wilson,  Philip,
                        ed.  
             The Musicall Prouerbis in the Garet at the New Lodge in the Parke of
                Lekingfelde.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1924.

DULCosVii14.First Lines:
ffor thy that god is inwardly the witteOf man and þewith to
                    him vnderstondyng…
DULCosVii14.Last Lines:
…ffor the vertu of this goode conseruatyfeAnd eke to atteyne
                    to mukest worthynesse
DULCosVii14.Note:
Latin couplet in rubric above each stanza, beginning Si deus est
                        animus nobis ut carmina dicunt…

GULHun259.First Lines:
Forthy that god is inwardly þe witteof man and yeuith hym
                    vnderstonding…
GULHun259.Last Lines:
…Here shal ye fynde that þou may gyde & ledestreight
                    to gode fame and bringe you to hir house
GULHun259.Attributed Author:
Cato þat noble & worthi clerke (see 5921, ‘Thus endith Caton…’, p.
                    50)

Chetham8009.First Lines:
for thi that God is inwardly the wytteOf man & yeuyth hym
                    vnderstanding…
Chetham8009.Last Lines:
…By two and two my metter for toknytNot causeth me but
                    symplenes of wit
Chetham8009.Note:
155 stanzas; Latin prose from which each translated before the stanzas
                    in rubric, beginning, Si deus est animus nobis…
Chetham8009.Attributed Title:
Explicit liber Catonis quod scripci E.N.P da michi quod merui (f.
                    75)

PierpontM775.First Lines:
For thi that god is inwardly the witteOf man and ȝeueth him
                    vndirstonding…
PierpontM775.Last Lines:
…By two and two my mater for to knyteNot causeth me but
                    simplenesse or witte

HunHM144.First Lines:
ffor thy that god is inwardly the wytOf man and geuyth hym
                    vndirstandyng…
HunHM144.Last Lines:
…Here haue I fonde that shal you guyde & ledeStreight to
                    goode fame & leue you in her house
HunHM144.Attributed Title:
Hic incipit magnus Catho (f. 114v); Explicit Catho
                    (f. 135v)

TCD519.First Lines:
ffor thy þat god gafe inwardly the wytOf man and yevith hym
                    vnderstondyng…
TCD519.Last Lines:
…Who lyueth well full wele eke dyeth heThat soule is sure of
                    grete felicyte
TCD519.Note:
Ends imperfectly. Latin before each stanza, beginning Si deus est
                        animus nobis vt carmina dicunt (above first).
